title: Boris Johnson dares opposition to trigger election
text:
Boris Johnson arrives at Downing Street after cutting short his trip to New York for the United Nations General Assembly | Isabel Infantes/AFP via Getty Images Boris Johnson dares opposition to trigger election Prime minister asks Jeremy Corbyn: ‘Does he in his heart even want to be prime minister any more?’

LONDON — Boris Johnson broke with convention Wednesday and challenged opposition parties to hold a vote of no confidence in his government.

The British prime minister, who twice failed to convince MPs to back a general election earlier this month, tried to trigger an election for the third time by giving his opponents until the end of the day to put forward a motion that would be voted on Thursday.

"Is [Labour's Jeremy Corbyn] going to dodge a vote of no confidence in me as prime minister in order to escape the verdict of the voters?" Johnson asked. "Does he in his heart even want to be prime minister anymore?"

Johnson argued that an election is needed to break the Brexit deadlock in the House of Commons and hopes to regain a Conservative majority in parliament, lost by his predecessor Theresa May, in order push a U.K. exit through. The prime minister has repeatedly promised to deliver Brexit by October 31 "do or die."

Earlier this month MPs sought to prevent the U.K. from leaving the EU without a deal by passing a new law — the Benn Act — forcing the prime minister to ask Brussels for an extension to negotiations if no deal is agreed by the time of the European Council summit in October.

Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn refused to take Johnson's bait, arguing that first his party wants to ensure the prime minister could not take the country out of the EU without a deal.

“He says he wants a general election. I want an election. It’s very simple — if you want an election, if he wants an election, get an extension [to Brexit negotiations] and let’s have an election,” Corbyn said.

Other opposition parties also rejected the government’s offer.

The Scottish National Party’s Westminster leader Ian Blackford said the opposition would not trigger a vote of no confidence until MPs had “removed the threat of no-deal,” saying the prime minister could not be trusted. A Liberal Democrat spokesperson said their party would not be accepting Johnson’s offer. Other opposition parties are expected to follow suit.

Their refusal leaves the Brexit process deadlocked. Johnson continues to pursue a new deal with the EU, while insisting the U.K. will leave on October 31 without one if necessary.

Johnson also said the government would comply with the law, despite the fact the Benn Act would prevent the U.K. leaving on October 31 without a deal, so long as the EU agrees to the extension when requested. Government spokespeople declined to explain how the prime minister intends to abide by the law, while also remaining committed to the October 31 date in all circumstances.

Johnson faced questions in the House of Commons the day after judges at the Supreme Court ruled that the prime minister's advice to the queen to suspend parliament for five weeks was “unlawful.”

The prime minister accused MPs of trying to block Brexit and said that by passing a law preventing a no-deal Brexit, parliament was undermining the U.K.'s position in negotiations with Brussels.

“I was told there was no chance of a new deal [with the EU27], but we are discussing a new deal … this is in spite the best efforts of … this parliament to wreck our negotiations by their attempts to take no-deal off the table,” he said.

"This parliament must either stand aside and either let this government get Brexit done or bring a vote of confidence and finally face a day of reckoning with the voters.”

In heated, often unruly exchanges in the House of Commons, Johnson was condemned by opposition MPs for his actions and his rhetoric, with some saying the Supreme Court decision had triggered a spike in online abuse.

Labour MP Paula Sherriff condemned what she called the prime minister’s “inflammatory” description of the Benn Act as a “surrender act.”

“Many of us [are] subject to death threats and abuse every single day and let me tell the prime minister they often quote his words, ‘surrender act’, ‘betrayal’, ‘traitor.’ We must moderate our language and it must come from the prime minister first,” she said.

Johnson responded: “I have never heard such humbug in all my life.”

However, he agreed that “tempers have become very ragged across the country and people feel the fever of Brexit has gone on too long,” but said “the best way to sort this out was to get Brexit done.”

Meanwhile, Conservative officials confirmed they intend the party’s annual conference to go ahead, and indicated that a motion would be put forward on Thursday seeking a three-day parliamentary break next week to enable Conservative MPs to attend.

Earlier, Corbyn told the BBC his party would not back a request for a break. “I won’t support anything that shuts down parliament until it is absolutely clear that the government will abide by the law and apply for an extension," the leader of the opposition said on BBC Radio 4's "Today" program.
description: Prime minister asks Jeremy Corbyn: ‘Does he in his heart even want to be prime minister any more?’
